review_title: Diverse Job with Poor Pay for South Kensington

review_title: not one to make a career or do full time
job_title: Explainer in London, England
pros: working in a big team with lots of like minded people
cons: no career progression opertunities- the only way up is to become a senior explainer and they get paid about £50 more a month and have to work every other weekend and essentially have to run the whole museum not a good report between on customer facing staff and managers managers do not pay any attention or utilise your existing skills training happens once in a blue moon so you do the same shows and demonstrations over and over for years Terrible terrible pay for the job your doing Asking for simple changes from management to make our lives easier and they are ignored the museum is never closed so you will work every bank holiday and usually most weekends it is impossible to get annual leave so everyone is burnt out Christmas leave is pulled out of a hat every year- there are some people who have not been home to see their families in years incredibly high staff turnover- most don't last past a few months you get no opportunity to work on creating resources or workshops- most of the day will be queue management and customer service

job_title: Visitor Experience Assistant in Manchester, England

job_title: Explainer in London, England
pros: Good sick pay policy and general attitude to taking time off for illness Can be very engaging and rewarding if you like informal education and working with children Good chance to work on public speaking etc. Very much a job that can be left at work, no expectation to check emails on your own time etc. Good onboarding process Good team spirit
cons: Full time is very exhausting for a pretty low salary Becomes very repetitive once you've learned the shows, very much the same day over and over Big turn over of staff so often short staffed leading to more exhausting schedules Can be hard to get holiday booked even quite far in advance, especially in school holiday times

job_title: People Assistant in York, England
pros: Nothing i can think of
cons: Everything about the place - worked at the national railway museum for around 2 months, my whole experience was bad. The training to do the job is basically non-existent, "refer to the book" is their idea of training. Now I am in a great job with thorough training where the company takes care of their employees i now realise how diabolical of a place this was and how useless the training was to do the job, maybe i wasn't good enough myself to do the job,but i offered myself up to extra training, they said they couldn't do that , so you wanted me to do better but can't find the time to have helped me... Maybe if they actually put the time and effort in needed to train people correctly it might not be as bad, very cliquey place, seems to be if your face fits then they'll help you, if not, see you later

job_title: Collections Staff in Bradford, Yorkshire and the Humber, England
pros:
Internationally important collections.
Numerous opportunities to network with others in your field - some great people work here.
Travel between sites and sometimes further afield - a pro, but too much travel is a con (exhausting).
Exciting creative opportunities, although the topic and venue will often be chosen for you.
Can be a lot of fun, particularly as an entry-level role and if you are not bothered about pay.
An opportunity to develop, learn and be increasingly productive.
cons:
Terrible pay. 
Low job security.
Corporate groupthink is the rule rather than the exception.
Tendency to chase external fashionable trends and anniversaries that are deeemed 'marketable' rather than do something original. 
Virtually all of the experienced curatorial staff were made redundant in the past 10-15 years.
Lack of commitment to vision or brand, (except in terms of maintaining the aforementioned groupthink).
Creative decision-making is top-down and tends to be opaque.
Increasing emphasis on academic partnerships, the database, and volunteers of various kinds as de facto alternatives to paid curatorial roles.
Performance reviews are too subjective and lack transparency - middle managers have too much power and behave accordingly.
Favouritism and a bullying culture exist, structurally entrenched by the pitting of at-risk employees against one another in restructures making team-working very difficult in some scenarios.
The restructures, which management conduct every few years, include fire-and-rehire practices - there is a strong desire to downgrade or eliminate roles that the organisation no longer values (resulting from the lack of commitment to vision already mentioned) underpinned by a reluctance to retain or retrain. Those who survive this round face a culture of fear - they could find themselves on the list for the next restructure.
Opportunities for promotion are scarce.

review_title: The Learning Department and Explainer team make it great, not the place itself
job_title: Explainer in London, England
pros:
Amazingly knowledgeable and supportive team
Lots of on-the-job training
You can build your repertoire of shows and demos fairly quickly
You don't need a science background for the job
We have been provided PPE since returning to work, and the managers will support you if someone is refusing to wear their mask or in some way giving you trouble.
cons:
We had to go on strike to be paid living wage
A major restructure has left many staff feeling angry and scared; upper management have not been transparent about what the driving force behind the restructure is and seem to be ignoring the impact of Covid-19 on everyone's mental and physical health.
You can end up falling behind other people in the same intake as you seemingly by chance. There is no guarantee you will progress in learning shows and demos at the same rate as your colleagues.
Very demanding job with little down-time - you are on your feet all day. You have to really love it to last more than a year or two.
Regular weekend and bank holiday working is required, and soon evening work will be as well. 
There is basically no room for career progression: as soon as a position becomes available the entire team applies and competes for that post.

review_title: I feel like I am Inspiring Futures working at Science Museum Group
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Manchester, England
pros:
A unique, special and great place to work. Working for SMG I feel as though the organisation is really beginning to invest in developing its culture through new museum brands, its engaging Mission and Values and how it keeps its employees informed.

Furthermore, there are some amazing 'behind the scenes benefits' working for the group. For example, behind the scenes tours of our stored collections, trialling new VR equipment and experiences and getting sneak peaks before the openings of new galleries and exhibitions. 

In terms of personal benefits, there is plenty of opportunity for flexibility. As long as you have the organisation in mind the managers here are open and very friendly.
cons: As a public sector, charitable, organisation it is hard to not always have the luxury of finance behind you. Some of our office work-spaces and systems could use a little TLC but at the end of the day its the people and environment that make it such a great place to work. Besides, who needs a massive slide in the middle of the office or ping-pong tables in the staff social area when we have awesome galleries, exhibitions and collections to look around during our lunch break!

job_title: Explainer in London, England
pros: Amazing environment to work in - privilege to be around certain objects, talent and special events. There is such talent in the staff, great place to learn and use as a step to a better role somewhere else. People are very friendly and supportive -  the best team I've ever worked in. Good opportunities to move roles internally.
cons: Terrible management and worst salary in the sector by far. Very little appreciation of staff. There is such a high rate of turnover, people don't stay for too long before they move on to a better paid role that values them more.

review_title: Expect to be very busy during weekends and holidays
job_title: Commercial Experiences Staff in London, England
pros:
- Team members are supportive, fun and great people which makes the workday enjoyable.
- Role is not difficult but can be fast-paced and varied on weekends.
- Very customer-oriented so good if you enjoy interacting with people. 
- There is the opportunity to work at exciting events since the Museum is often used as a popular hosting venue. You might meet many a famous face.
cons:
- You must be a very good and patient communicator, you will come across LOTS of tourists with little spoken-english ability, misbehaving children, rude visitors, stressed parents etc.

- Lots of things in the museum are frequently broken (flight simulation rides, lifts, escalators, interactive exhibits), and there are sometime very long queues for popular experiences. Visitors will act like all of this is your fault because you are front of house.  

- Turnover of team members is quite high. Many people work part time as students so leave when their degree is up.  That being said, friendship among ex-staff members is quite strong.

job_title: Visitor Services Assistant in South Kensington, England
pros: Its s good way to gain customer service experience and get a nice free day put for your family.  You can become good friends with your colleagues. A lot of grateful visitors who are happy with your service. Looks good on the CV.
cons: however don't expect to feel respected by people above you. They keep forcing useless changes on you that affects your workday and adds to your workload just to see if it works out. There is a mouse problem which no one ever does anything about.  Everything breaks down (machines, lifts etc.) and you end up basically doing physical labour. Short staffed a lot of the time because staff hate being there and call in sick a lot. It feels like they won't let you stop selling the tickets even if the place was on fire. Rude visitors and quit a few racists

job_title: Anonymous Employee in London, England
pros:
Great peers in the team you work with
Amazing buildings and contents in the form of one of the most prestige museum collections in the world.
Staff discounts in the shops and cafes
Reciprocal agreements with other museums and cultural organisations across london and the UK.
cons:
Horrible visitors can ruin a day, and some are downright awful.
The current customer relationship managment system still needs a lot of work. 
Staff room is badly equipped and not the nicest place to take breaks.
Not enough training time for the roles you undertake.
Unpaid lunch breaks mean an 8hr day becomes 7 paid.
"Revolving door" is fast.

job_title: Visitors Services in London, England
